message: Happy Mother's Day to all of the strong and inspiring mothers in #AL06, including my wife Ann!
It's a honor to be recognized by the American Conservative Union for my consistent conservative voting record.
I will always support our brave men and women in blue who protect our loved ones daily. During National Police Week, take a moment to thank a police officer for their service.
Good to be in Gardendale for the Sixth Congressional District Spring Mayors Luncheon last week. Special thanks to Mayor Stan Hogeland, Steve Sewell, and the City of Gardendale.

I enjoyed my visit to Clanton Intermediate School where I spoke to students in Ms. Chaney White’s 4th grade class. Special thanks to Chilton County Schools Superintendent Tommy Glasscock and Principal Louise Pitts.

We’re currently witnessing an unprecedented global cyberattack. Attacks such as this threaten our economy, our national security. This highlights the need for law enforcement to be trained at local, state and national levels to recognize and combat this activity. I was proud to vote in favor of H.R. 1616 authorizing into law the National Computer Forensics Institute (NCFI) located in Hoover. The NCFI has trained more than 6,000 officials from all across America so far in the latest methods and techniques of investigating cyber crimes.
Yesterday I spoke on the House floor in support of #HR1616 and the National Computer Forensics Institute which we are fortunate to have in Hoover.
Tune in to the Facebook Live I'm doing right now with Rep. John Ratcliffe about the National Computer Forensics Institute!

I was grateful for the opportunity to participate in a Homeland Security Committee hearing during Police Week regarding the important role dogs play in the security of our nation. I believe we should have more canine units deployed at airports across the country, but TSA needs to focus on amplifying their canine units with American bred and trained dogs rather than ones from foreign countries.  WATCH here:
It was great to be in Coosa County Saturday for the 2017 Hatchet Creek Festival. Special thanks to Beverly Bass and Sharon Haynes.
Looking forward to seeing everyone tomorrow morning for Pastries with Palmer!

Over the years our government has drifted away from Federalism and the system of governing our Founding Fathers created. The creation of the Task Force on Intergovernmental Affairs will greatly aid in our ability to steer our country back on the right path with a robust economy, job creation, and each branch of government properly functioning. Read more about the Task Force here:

Alabamians from all walks of life have felt the strain of their healthcare costs increasing dramatically each year due to the misnamed Affordable Care Act. Yesterday, the Department of Health and Human Services published a report showing just how bad this system has been for people in Alabama. From 2013 to 2017, the average monthly premium rose by 223% in our state, the highest increase in the country!

I introduced the Assigning Proper Placement of Executive Action Lawsuits (APPEAL) Act, H.R. 2660, today to give the federal courts in the District of Columbia exclusive jurisdiction over any challenge to an Executive order, action, or memorandum.  Litigants challenging a President’s Executive orders should not be able to forum shop for a court they believe will provide the most favorable judgment. We must ensure our judicial branch operates equally and fairly for all presidents, eliminating chaos and bias. The President of the United States, regardless of party or beliefs, has the authority to issue Executive orders, actions and memorandums. The authority does not belong to activist judges bending the law as they see fit.
‪Today we remember and honor our men and women who made the ultimate sacrifice to keep our country safe for all Americans. #MemorialDay ‬
It was great having my friend, Rep. John Ratcliffe, in town to tour the National Computer Forensics Institute today.
Rep. John Ratcliffe and I stopped by Talk 99.5 this morning to discuss the importance of cyber security and the vital work being done in Hoover by the National Computer Forensics Institute.

Our nation owes it to our law enforcement officers to give them the best training and most advanced resources possible. Thanks to the NCFI, we can help provide them with both, so they can be successful in their mission of keeping our communities safe.   READ more of my op-ed with Rep. John Ratcliffe in The Hill:

73 years ago the brave Allied forces stormed the beaches of Normandy. These men were someone's sons, someone's brothers, someone's husbands. They were willing to make the ultimate sacrifice in honor of their countries and their loved ones. We will always remember their noble actions on #DDay.
It was a great honor speaking to the Competitive Enterprise Institute today about my conservative efforts in Congress and the future of our nation.

Today we voted on the Financial CHOICE Act to relieve financial institutions from growth stunting regulations, end all taxpayer bailouts, and stop investors from making risky decisions with taxpayer money. Each and every American deserves the opportunity to achieve financial independence, and we'll help them get there by holding Wall Street and Washington accountable.
Great spending the morning with students from across Alabama. They're in DC this week for the Alabama Rural Electric Youth Tour.

This morning I was with my Republican colleagues practicing for the annual charity Congressional Baseball Game – a game that this year, ironically, is to honor the victims of the recent terror attacks in England – when a lone gunman walked out by the third baseline and opened fire. I was about 20 yards away from the shooter. It was reported that I received treatment. This was due to me injuring my leg as I sought cover. My thoughts and prayers are with Congressman Steve Scalise and the others injured in this senseless tragedy. I am thankful for the bravery shown by the Capitol Police who were present and the quick action by the Alexandria, Va. Police Department in their response which undoubtedly saved many innocent lives today.

Happy Father's Day. This day is a reminder of how much America needs for all fathers to strive to be a role models to their children.  I am especially thankful to be able to celebrate today with my children.   On this Father's Day, please join me in taking a moment to pray for the full recovery of Congressman Steve Scalise, Matt Mika, Zach Barth and Capitol Police Special Agents David Bailey and Crystal Griner as they continue to recover from their wounds from this past week's attack against members of the Republican baseball team.
Alabama's Sixth District is made up of six counties: Bibb, Blount, Coosa, Chilton, Jefferson and Shelby. Do you know what each of the six is known for?

It was a honor to attend the deployment ceremony Saturday in Homewood for the 135th Expeditionary Sustainment Command of the Alabama Army National Guard. Special thanks to Brigadier General Sylvester Cannon and Sergeant Scott Brannon.
Looking forward to seeing everyone tomorrow morning!

The Environmental Protection Agency took a major step towards returning power to the states by overturning the Waters of the United States (WOTUS) rule, which would have been detrimental to Alabama. I am pleased the Trump Administration is keeping their promise to let states govern and not let Washington rule over intermittent streams, creeks and ponds, including those found on private property.
Great seeing Carson McDonald this morning. He won #AL06's Congressional Art Competition this year with his photo "Untitled"!
Happy Fourth of July! Today and every day I am proud to be an American.

I'm in Congress to look after the future of America. An added bonus is when I get to look at America's bright future in the eye. Always happy to see my Legislative Director's daughter, Lyle, in the office!
Great meeting with students from the University of Alabama today. They're up in DC interning for the summer.

Special Agent David Bailey dropped by the Republican Study Committee and I had a chance to talk with him about what happened at the baseball practice on June 14th. Special Agent Bailey showed great courage that day. I and the others who were on the practice field that day are profoundly grateful for him putting himself in the line of fire to protect us. Please keep him and Special Agent Crystal Griner in your prayers.
To me it is vital we bring down health care premiums for every American. I hope my colleagues in the Senate believe the same.
I was honored to receive the Freedom Fighter Award today from FreedomWorks.

The budget passed by the House Budget Committee is far from perfect, but it begins to address the nation’s financial crisis. I voted in favor of advancing the budget for a few reasons. According to GAO, the government made more than $140 billion in improper payments in 2016 alone. With this budget, we will save over $700 billion through common sense, stopping improper payments. The budget provides the Department of Defense robust funding to be used for troop training, equipment, and improved readiness in the wake of unprecedented national security threats. The Department of Homeland Security will also be fully funded allowing us to protect our borders and keep America safe from outside threats. While there are more steps and additions necessary to improve this budget and our country’s fiscal health, we have taken the first step to building a better America and a better economy for future generations.
Great getting to spend some time this morning with BigTime Ministries while they're in DC. I hope y'all enjoyed your Capitol tour.

Every year I have the honor and privilege of nominating outstanding students from the Sixth District of Alabama for an appointment to our nation’s service academies. Receiving an appointment to a service academy is a competitive process with each academy having an acceptance rate of less than 15%.  I am pleased to announce the 14 students from Alabama’s Sixth District who received my nomination and accepted an offer from a U.S. Service Academy.  Please join me in congratulating these outstanding individuals and their families as they embark to learn at the highest levels and serve America in extraordinary ways.  Find out which students received appointments at the link below:

I am deeply saddened to hear of the passing of retired Brigadier General Everett Holle. His service to our nation and this community spanned more than six decades, both on the local and national level. Holle spent over 40 years as an announcer, director, writer, producer and Program Director at Birmingham’s NBC 13 before retiring in 1991, earning numerous awards and being inducted into the Alabama Broadcasters Association Hall of Fame in 2012. In the 1950s, Holle was pulled out of what was supposed to be a two-year stint in the U.S. Army and sent to Washington, D.C., where he led the United States Army’s Radio, TV and Motion Picture department. His military service continued with numerous assignments with the  87th US Army Maneuver Area Command until Holle retired as Brigadier General in 1985. In recognition of his work in the field of communication, the University of Alabama College of Communication and Information Sciences annually gives the Holle Awards for Excellence and Creativity in Communication. General Holle was a tireless volunteer to many organizations, including the Boy Scouts of America where he served on the Executive Board and for which he received numerous awards. More personally, I remember Everett Holle for his work as a broadcaster on Channel 13. I am honored that General Holle served the 6th Congressional District for many years as a member of the Military Academy Nominating Committee, interviewing students from Alabama’s 6th Congressional District for appointments to this nations’ military academies. My family, my staff, and I send our prayers to General Holles’ family and friends. He was a giant in our community and will be sorely missed.
I enjoyed speaking to the Shelby County City Clerks Association at their luncheon today in Chelsea. Special thanks to President Becky Landers and Chelsea Mayor Tony Picklesimer.
Glad to tour Hoover Toyota and talk with some of their 150 employees. Special thanks to owner Gordon Stewart and Birmingham Automobile Dealers Association Executive Director Jennifer Whisenant.
Good to speak at the Alabama Restaurant & Hospitality Association Board of Directors Meeting at the Birmingham Marriott. Special thanks to ARHA President and CEO Mindy Hanan.
I am hosting two Town Halls next week! I hope to see you there.  CLICK the link below to learn more.

It was my pleasure to present Madison Jones of Wilsonville, AL with the Congressional Award for service to her community and self-improvement. Congress established the award in 1979 to recognize initiative, achievement and service in young people in four areas: voluntary public service, personal development, physical fitness, and expedition or exploring.  In earning her Congressional Medal Award Bronze medal, Madison volunteered at her local library and planned events for the children’s department. She learned the importance of patience and improved in her ability to work and direct others. For her Personal Development, Madison planted a garden and grew vegetables for her family. She learned how to prepare the soil and how to keep the garden thriving throughout the year. Madison’s Physical Fitness goal was to increase her strength to do 20 push-ups. For her Expedition, Madison spent three days and two nights exploring the historical sites in Clayton, Georgia, learning about the town and what it was like from the 1800s-to-1900s.  Madison, a junior who homeschools through the Shades Mountain Independent Church Academy, is the daughter of  Melissa and Barry Smith. She has learned how to set a goal and push herself beyond what she may have thought she was capable, and for that she is awarded the Congressional Medal Award Bronze Medal. Congratulations to Madison Jones. We look forward to seeing what she accomplishes in the future.
Great to attend the Alabama Farmers Federation 45th Annual Commodity Producers Conference and Expo. Special thanks to ALFA President Jimmy Parnell and ALFA Legislative Programs Director Mitt Walker.
I appreciate Mr. Lior Haiat, Israeli Consul General for Alabama, for stopping by the office to meet.
Touring the Kamtek (Magna International) automotive stamping and aluminum casting facility, which employees over 900 people. Special thanks to General Manager John Hackett.

Touring the voestalpine Nortrak railway turnouts and track facility in Tarrant-Birmingham. Special thanks to voestalpine Automotive Body Parts Inc. President Phillip Schultz and VP of Operations Jeff Phelps.
Great visit to the Galleria Woods senior living center in Hoover. Special thanks to Saralyn Millwee and Paul Sedley.
I enjoyed speaking at the Blount-Oneonta Chamber of Commerce luncheon. Special thanks to Chamber Executive Director Aimee Wilson and all of the secondary school leadership ambassadors.
Great visit to Bibb County to speak at the Chamber of Commerce breakfast in Brent. Special thanks to Chamber Director Valerie Cook.
It was good to visit with Chilton County mayors, commissioners, law enforcement, and other elected officials in Jemison. Special thanks to Jemison Mayor Eddie Reed and Shannon Welch.
I stopped by the Bibb Medical Center in Centreville to visit with staff and physicians. Special thanks to BMC CEO Joseph Marchant.
Looking forward to seeing everyone this week at our town halls!
Calera Town Hall
Hueytown Town Hall
Hueytown Part 2

It’s always good to visit with businesses in the district, such as Lucky’s Foodland grocery store in Montevallo. Special thanks to Alabama Grocers Association President Ellie Taylor, Mitchell Grocery Corp. Director Wade Payne, and Lucky’s Store Manager Clay Goar.
We hosted a lunch and discussion with mayors from throughout the 6th Congressional district. Special thanks to the City of Hoover and the Hoover Public Library.
Enjoyed visiting Specification Rubber Products, Inc.’s headquarters and manufacturing facility in Alabaster, which has 60 employees. Special thanks to company President Steven Smith.
In case you missed it, I was on News Radio 105.5 WERC with JT this morning. Catch up at the link below.
Are you excited for the total solar eclipse tomorrow? Check out NASA - National Aeronautics and Space Administration's guide for it!

Did you know that a team of engineering students from The University of Alabama will be sending a balloon up during the eclipse? It will monitor the outside temperature to get a better understanding on how the eclipse effects high altitude temperature.

If you weren't able to make it to our town halls last week, don't fret! Tomorrow morning at 8AM I am doing a live radio town hall on Talk 99.5 with Matt Murphy & Andrea Lindenberg. I hope you listen and call in with any questions you might have.
In case you weren't able to listen in this morning, catch up on our radio town hall with Matt Murphy & Andrea Lindenberg below!
My thoughts and prayers go out to those affected by Hurricane Harvey. As the brave first responders continue to aid those in need, please keep praying for their safety.
I enjoyed speaking at the Alabama Policy Institute Luncheon in Birmingham. Special thanks to API President Caleb Crosby and all API staff and supporters.
Thank you to the hardworking Americans who make our country so great! I hope you and your family have a fun and safe Labor Day.

Many organizations in Washington such as March for Life, Americans United for Life and the National Right to Life Committee exist solely to protect life. Yet the D.C. city council is attempting to force these organizations to bow down and comply with an ordinance that goes against their religious beliefs. Such flagrant disregard of religious liberty as guaranteed by the Constitution cannot be blindly ignored.  READ my piece in The Hill at the link below.
Today the House passed the much needed Hurricane Harvey aid package. We must also continue praying for those affected by Hurricane Harvey during their recovery efforts.
I am honored to be named a "Heartbeat Bill Hero". H.R.490, the Heartbeat Protection Act of 2017, is a common sense, pro-life bill which I am proud to be a cosponsor of.

Yesterday's vote on raising the debt limit for 3 months while also providing additional funding for relief to the victims of Hurricane Harvey is another example of how Congress allows itself to be forced into bad choices. By attaching funding for the victims of Hurricane Harvey to a short-term debt-limit increase the Texas and Louisiana victims of Hurricane Harvey were made hostage to the vote on the debt limit that denied us any opportunity to get needed changes in government spending. Earlier in the week I joined my colleagues in voting for the first round of funding for FEMA to continue to provide much-needed relief for the Hurricane Harvey victims. I am more than willing to continue to provide that support in a way that makes sense and does not allow massive amounts of pork spending to be included. That said, America is facing another gathering storm, but it is not a natural storm, it is a fiscal storm that will affect every man, woman, boy and girl in our country if we do not take appropriate action. This is a man-made disaster that we can and must avoid.

Sixteen years ago today we witnessed one of the darkest days in US history. A terrorist attack against innocent civilians that resulted in the loss of almost 3,000 lives. Earlier this year, Ann and I visited Ground Zero in New York City and walked around the memorial looking at the names of those who were lost that day in the World Trade Towers. It was a somber and moving reminder that each name represented a loved one...a son or daughter, a husband or wife, a brother or sister...a family.   Today we remember those who were lost and those who have given their lives in defense of our freedom since that day, including the 106 Alabama servicemen and women. On this day we also take great pride and great hope in the strength of our nation and our ability to come together in times of tragedy to help one another and to stand together in defense of our freedom.

Please stay weather aware as Hurricane Irma goes through #AL06. The US National Weather Service Birmingham Alabama is a great source for staying up to date on the latest forecasts, warnings, and watches.

Members of my DC staff joined the USO today to assemble care packages for service members who are supporting Hurricane Harvey and Irma relief and recovery efforts.  We are grateful to the service members for their selfless dedication to our nation.

It was truly an honor to receive the Power of Service award from Yellowhammer News. But it would not have been possible to earn this award without the hard work of my great staff and the constant support from my amazing wife Ann.
Happy Birthday to the United States Air Force! Thank you for 70 years of dedicated service to our country.

"In questions of power ... let no more be heard of confidence in man, but bound him down from mischief by the chains of the constitution." With Constitution Day being just yesterday, these words from Thomas Jefferson should resonate with all Americans, especially those who serve in public office. The Constitution binds us down from the mischief of discriminating against individuals based on religion, and this includes those of the Catholic faith.  Senator Dianne Feinstein, in a recent confirmation hearing for Amy Barrett, nominated to the 7th Circuit Court of Appeals, ignored the establishing a religious test chain, and accused Ms. Barrett of being unable to follow the law because of her religion.  An individuals deeply held religious beliefs cannot and should not bar them from public service. Those who revere the document should pursue public service. Senator Feinstein and others need to be reminded of this on Constitution Day and every day.

Last night I had the pleasure of hosting our annual U.S. Service Academy night. Over 130 people representing 30 high schools attended the event at the Vestavia Hills Library, to meet with representatives from the five US Service Academies (Army, Navy, Air Force, Merchant Marine, and Coast Guard) and Marion Military Institute and to learn about the nomination process for high school students interested in seeking an appointment to one of our academies.   What an honor to meet these future leaders and their parents, who love their country and seek the opportunity to serve it at the highest level. I look forward to nominating the best and the brightest from the Sixth Congressional District to attend our nation’s Service Academies again this year.

I believe it is vital every school in America teaches their students about the Constitution. Olive J. Dodge Elementary School in Mobile provides their students an interactive learning experience by ringing a bell in celebration of the U.S. Constitution. They rang their bell today at 2PM and invited me to join them in their celebration, which I gladly joined in on from my Birmingham District Office.
Great visit to Hayden last night to speak at the West Blount Chamber of Commerce meeting. Special thanks to Jim and Dolores Fort and the Hayden Middle School Ambassadors.

I enjoyed speaking at the Trussville Chamber of Commerce luncheon and was honored to receive the Spirit of Enterprise Award from the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. Special thanks to Trussville Chamber Director Diane Poole and U.S. Chamber of Commerce Southeast Manager Clark Thomason.

I was pleased to attend the Mercedes-Benz USI event celebrating 20 years of vehicle production in Alabama. It was also announced that the company will be expanding their footprint in the state by investing more than $1 billion dollars. The new facilities will include a new Global Logistics Center and after-sales parts hub in Bibb County as well as a battery plant and electric SUV production in Tuscaloosa County. The expansion is expected to create more than 600 new jobs.
I just experienced my best day in Congress. Steve Scalise just returned to the House. God has answered many, many prayers.

President Trump’s action today in waiving the Jones Act for Puerto Rico provides 10 days of temporary relief.  The President’s authority in this area is limited.  In a humanitarian crisis, we must focus on helping others and saving lives. Next week, I plan to introduce Jones Act legislation, which would provide extended relief.  Right now Puerto Rico needs our help as they rebuild and recover from Hurricane Maria.  The people of Puerto Rico need extended not temporary relief to rebuild their infrastructure, their homes and put their lives back together. At a time when every dime will count, it is the right thing to do to extend the waiver.
We had a great time at our annual Service Academy Night. Find out more about the nomination process here → palmer.house.gov/services/military-academy-nominations

I was proud to cast my vote tonight in favor of the Pain Capable Unborn Child Protection Act, of which I am a co-sponsor. Saving the lives of millions of unborn children is something we should all want to do, and it's something that this bill does. Science confirms that unborn children can feel pain at or before 20 weeks into the pregnancy. Simple human dignity requires that we should save his or her life.

The Congress has the responsibility to act when enacted laws prove to be burdensome. This is especially true in a humanitarian crisis. Our bill, the Puerto Rico Humanitarian Relief Act, provides Puerto Ricans with extended relief from the Jones Act to help them put their lives back together as they rebuild their homes, their communities and their infrastructure. The cost of goods in Puerto Rico is already substantially higher due to Jones Act related shipping costs, and, especially in a humanitarian crisis, every penny counts.

It was a pleasure to meet with Hoover Mayor Frank Brocato and Allan Rice, Executive Director for the City of Hoover, to discuss issues facing one of Alabama’s largest and fastest growing cities. I always appreciate hearing from our Sixth District mayors about their views on moving this area forward.
Happy 242nd Birthday to the U.S. Navy! Thank you to brave men and women who proudly defend our great nation.
It was great meeting with students from Advent Episcopal Elementary School on their visit to our nation’s capital this past week!

It was a pleasure to host a luncheon for state legislators from Alabama’s 6th Congressional District. Regular meetings such as this give us an opportunity to discuss issues that affect our state’s residents, to better understand how the federal and state governments can work together to prepare for the future of the 6th District and all of Alabama. I look forward to working with members of state and local government in my role on the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, where I chair the Subcommittee on Intergovernmental Affairs.

I was pleased to attend the groundbreaking ceremony for the new Wallace State-Oneonta Center. The education and training center will provide residents of Blount County with opportunities for postsecondary education as well as career and technical training. Special thanks to Wallace State President Vicki Karolewics and Wallace State-Oneonta Center Director Kelley Jones.
Looking forward to seeing everyone tomorrow morning at Pastries with Palmer!

I toured the UAB Center for AIDS Research (CFAR) and the 1917 Clinic, which provides comprehensive health care to patients living with HIV in the Birmingham and surrounding areas. The UAB CFAR is a NIH-designated center and is one of the nation’s leaders in HIV/AIDS research and treatment. Special thanks to Dr. Mike Saag, Director of the UAB Center for AIDS Research and Associate Dean for Global Health.

Good to be in Mountain Brook to celebrate the opening of the Mayor Terry Oden Police and Fire Training Facility. Special thanks to Mayor Stewart Welch, former Mayor Terry Oden, and all of the dedicated police and fire department members.

I had a good meeting with pharmacy students from Samford University, during which we discussed patient medical needs in underserved areas of the state. Special thanks to Academy of Student Pharmacists Policy VP Shea Summerlin Terry.
Always great to visit Blount County for the annual Covered Bridge Festival, as the county celebrates its history and three remaining covered bridges.

Good visit to the University of Alabama’s Joint Electronic Crimes Task Force (JECTF) lab in Tuscaloosa, which assists law enforcement in processing digital evidence. Special thanks to UA Director of Security Craig Caldwell, JECTF Academic Director Dr. Diana Dolliver, and UAPD Capt. Clay Hickman.

I am saddened to hear the news that former U.S. Congressman Jim Martin passed away Monday at the age of 99. Jim, born in Tarrant, Alabama, was part of the “the Greatest Generation,’’ and he lived a life of public service as a Congressman and businessman after serving our nation in World War II, where he was among the first American troops to liberate a concentration camp near Ohrdruf, Germany.  Perhaps his most enduring impact on the state came while heading the Department of Conservation and Natural Resources under former Governor Guy Hunt, where he established the “Forever Wild” program. Jim’s legacy of service will continue. I will miss my friend and Ann and I will remember his family in our prayers.

With the introduction of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, House Republicans took the first major step toward putting America back on the path to a strong and vibrant economy. Americans deserve to keep more of the money they worked hard to earn and it is vital that we deliver on this promise to the American people. It has been 31 years since the last overhaul of our nation’s tax code, so these fundamental reforms that lower taxes on individuals and businesses are long past due. These reforms, if implemented, will deliver the type of sustained economic growth that has been sorely lacking in recent years.
False and widely spread talking points from some Democrats about our House Republican tax reform plan were noticed by the Washington Post and earned them four Pinocchios from the Post.  Read more:
It was great to have Congressman Scalise at the Alabama-LSU game on Saturday.

The selfless service by the men and women of the United States Armed Forces is what keeps our nation great. This November I will be featuring stories and pictures from our brave veterans on our website. Please join me in honoring our veterans by sharing their stories and thanking all veterans for their service.  For more information on how to share your stories and photos, click the link below.

Today and everyday we thank and recognize our veterans for their brave and selfless sacrifice to our great nation. May we never forget what they have done to keep our homeland the land of the free and the home of the brave.

I was honored to attend the 2017 National Veterans Award Dinner. This year’s award was presented to the Navajo Code Talkers, for their invaluable service to our nation during WWII. Also recognized was Dave Wood, for his work with the Veterans Airlift Command, which flies post 9/11 combat wounded veterans to medical facilities throughout the country at no charge.

My colleagues and I took a significant step towards providing American families much needed and meaningful tax relief. The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act lowers rates for individuals and families and makes much needed changes designed to spur the type of sustained economic growth that will benefit every American. The American people have been waiting over three decades for this kind of reform and I hope that my colleagues in the Senate will move quickly so that we can reconcile differences and make improvements in order to deliver on the promise of tax reform to the American people. One of the primary reasons I ran for Congress was to have the opportunity to help make major reforms that help American families and that help make our nation more secure, more prosperous and on a path to fiscal stability. Throughout this process our focus has been on lowering rates for taxpayers, making sure American corporations can compete in the world economy, cutting taxes and red tape to promote small business startups and help them grow, and making our tax code simpler and predictable to promote more investment. These are the essentials that will lead to vibrant and sustainable economic growth and that will put more money in people’s paychecks.  While we are excited about what we are doing with this bill, our tax reform effort is not a ‘one and done’. We will continue to work year-after-year to ensure that our tax code works for the American economy and works for all Americans.

On Thursday November 23rd, most Americans will gather with their families and friends to celebrate a uniquely American holiday, a day of thanksgiving, a day devoted to remembering the blessings of God. Most Americans connect this uniquely American holiday with a romanticized version of the Pilgrims at Plymouth Colony. But there is more to the story … it is also a story of America’s first experiment with socialism. It is generally known that the Pilgrims settled at Plymouth Colony in December 1620 and suffered terribly through their first winter in America with about half of their members dying from sickness, starvation or exposure. Even though Squanto taught the Pilgrims how to grow corn and members of the Wampanoag tribe helped them with hunting, trapping and fishing, the harvest of their crops yielded barely enough to support the colony. In the fall of 1621, although things were still very tough, they were still thankful for what they had and declared a three-day feast which they shared with about Wampanoag 90 braves who brought deer and wild fowl. The following year, the Pilgrims once again failed to produce enough food to adequately sustain their colony. But it wasn’t bad farming practices that resulted in another poor harvest, it was the colony’s requirement that whatever was produced, whether food or clothing, was to be put in a common storehouse and shared with everyone in the colony. According to the journal kept by William Bradford, the first governor of Plymouth Colony, “… all profits & benefits that are got by trade, working, fishing, or any other means” were to be deposited into a common storehouse and that “all such persons as are of this colony, are to have their meat, drink, apparel, and all provisions out of the common stock.” This meant that each member of the community was entitled to take from the storehouse what they needed, regardless of how much or how little they contributed. The problem, as Bradford found out, was that the Plymouth Colony version of socialism undermined work ethic, killed personal initiative and bred contempt for those who were unwilling to work. Because all that the colonists produced was held in common and all members of the colony were entitled to be provided for from the common storehouse, there was no incentive for people to work any harder than necessary and many able-bodied people simply quit working altogether. After the dismal harvest of 1622, Governor Bradford recorded in his journal that “… they began to think how they might raise as much corn as they could, and obtain a better crop.” He and the other colony leaders observed that the redistributionist system “…was found to breed much confusion and discontent, and retard much employment that would have been to their benefit and comfort.” Consequently, Bradford and the Plymouth elders changed the system from the socialist redistribution of the harvest, or as liberals like to call it today—spreading the wealth around—and adopted a free market plan. In their new plan they assigned ownership of a plot of land to each family and allowed them to keep what they produced for themselves or allowed them to sell or trade it. The bountiful harvest of 1623 proved that market incentives work. Bradford wrote, “This had very good success, for it made all hands very industrious, so as much more corn was planted than otherwise would have been by any other means the Governor or any other could use ….” Bradford acknowledged, “… instead of famine now God gave them plenty and the face of things was changed, to the rejoicing of the hearts of many.” Socialism in Plymouth Colony was a complete and tragic failure. After the colony implemented a free market system, Bradford wrote that from that point “… any general want or famine hath not been amongst them since to this day.” In fact, the harvest of 1624 was so plentiful that colonists were not only able to provide for themselves and others in the colony, they were also able to start exporting corn to England. In other words, the Pilgrims learned that private property and free markets were a benefit to everyone in the colony…the able-bodied and the disabled. When you gather with family and friends this Thanksgiving to give thanks for God’s blessings, you should also give thanks for Governor Bradford and the Pilgrim settlers of Plymouth Colony. They not only laid the spiritual foundation for America, they also laid the foundation for private property and a free market system that has allowed us to care for our families and others in need and that has been a blessing to Americans for over 390 years.

It was great to tour the National Weather Service Forecast office in Calera. This office provides official forecasts and warnings for 39 Alabama counties, including the Birmingham metro area. Special thanks to Kevin Laws and John De Block.

Last week I visited the Magnolia Creek Treatment Center in Shelby County. This center provides care and a supportive environment to adult women with mental health and eating disorders. Special thanks to CEO Linda Smith.

This week I cosponsored the Congressional Accountability and Hush Fund Elimination Act to bring transparency to the U.S. Congress. This bill would:  Require disclosure within 30 calendar days of all settlement payments funded by taxpayers, the reason for the payment and the nature of the allegation, and the member of Congress or congressional staffer implicated in the matter.  Prohibit the future use of taxpayer dollars to pay sexual harassment and sexual assault claims against members of Congress and staff.  Prohibit members of Congress from using office budgets to camouflage payments.  Require members of Congress and staff that have ever been named in a sexual harassment or sexual assault settlement paid for by taxpayers reimburse the U.S. Treasury with interest.  Any individual who received an award may make public statements about the claims notwithstanding the terms of a nondisclosure agreement and nondisclosure agreements cannot be made a condition of any future settlements.

I enjoyed visiting Mortimer Jordan High School in Kimberly to talk to students about leadership and laying a solid foundation for their future. Special thanks to History Department Chairman Mark Ridgeway.
It was great visiting Oak Mountain High School to speak with students and encourage them to make a difference in life. Special thanks to government and politics teacher Susan Schwartz.

Good to be in Hayden for the West Blount Fire District year-end celebration. The event allowed the community to thank and recognize all of the firefighters that serve the area. Special thanks to Chief J.J. Ivey and Secretary Dolores Fort.

As a staunch supporter of the 2nd Amendment, I am a proud cosponsor of and voted in favor of H.R. 38 today. This bill protects the constitutional right for law-abiding citizens to keep and bear arms and ensures that the right does not end when you cross a state line. Overreaching restrictions placed on gun ownership are not only unconstitutional, they inevitably harm law-abiding citizens and do little to dissuade the illegal use of firearms. It is important to note that this bill would not apply to individuals prohibited from possessing a firearm under current federal law.

This semester Mike Rohdy served as an intern in our Washington, DC office. Mike is a senior at Samford University majoring in Economics and minoring in Spanish. His favorite part of his internship was meeting the great people from Alabama’s Sixth District and showing them around the Capitol. Thank you for your hard work, Mike!
Glad to hear my friend Congressman Mo Brooks’ surgery went well. Ann and I send him prayers and well wishes for a speedy recovery!

It was my honor to be the keynote speaker at the at ninth annual Wreaths Across America ceremony held Saturday at the Alabama National Cemetery in Montevallo. Wreaths are laid at the grave of each of the 5,400 servicemen and women and their families who are interred, along with honoring those Prisoners of War and Missing in Action who have never returned home. To all the families and friends of those who now rest here in this special place we give our heart-felt and deepest thanks. God bless you and give you peace and in some way help you to know the gratitude that we feel, but can never adequately express. I would especially like to thank Bob Barefield and the Support Committee for the ALNC, the Bessemer Civil Air Patrol, and the estimated crowd of 3,000 who attended Saturday’s event to honor American’s heroes.

The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act will provide a much needed tax break for hardworking Americans for the first time in 31 years. Our tax plan not only puts more money in the pockets of the American people, but will also launch economic growth. Over the previous eight years our economy only grew at an anemic 1.8 percent per year because businesses were shackled by a complicated and burdensome tax code that was designed for a 1986 economy. The tax reform bill the House just passed removes the shackles and brings our tax code up to date with today’s economy and with American families and workers. I look forward to the Senate favorably voting on the tax bill so we can give the American people a Christmas gift that will keep on giving.

The selection of Alabama’s Dannelly Field for the F-35 Joint Strike Fighter Mission is a testament to Alabama’s workforce and the men and women who represent the 187th Fighter Wing.  I’m especially proud of the fact that the 187th, the successors of the famed Tuskegee Airmen, will now be flying our nation’s most advanced fighter.  The entire team of pilots and ground personnel of the 187th have served our nation with skill and distinction and are deserving of the opportunity to continue their service to our nation and the state of Alabama with the F-35, America’s next generation fighter jet.
Wishing you and your family a very Merry Christmas!
Happy New Year! Ann and I wish you and your family a happy and joyous 2017.
Tomorrow marks the start of the 115th Congress. I'm ready to get back to work and focus on lessening harmful regulations to help Make America Great Again.

It was a great privilege to stand on the House floor for the second time pledging to support and defend the Constitution. I look forward to serving the great people of Alabama’s Sixth District in the 115th Congress and bringing our conservative values to Washington, D.C. I believe we can accomplish a lot over the next two years and I am eager to get back to work.
I am proud to call William Smith my Chief of Staff.

I was pleased to be an original co-sponsor and vote in favor of the Regulations from the Executive in Need of Scrutiny (REINS) Act of 2017, H.R. 26, last night. This bill will prevent wasteful spending and unnecessary regulations imposed by bureaucrats by requiring regulations which would cost the economy more than $100 million to be approved by Congress. By bringing major regulations under congressional oversight, we can help protect the American people and American businesses.

My democratic colleagues are accusing us of trying to #MakeAmericaSickAgain, but in reality America has become more sick under Obamacare and this is proven by the mortality rate, as reported by NPR. When we repeal and replace Obamacare, providing access to quality healthcare, we'll save lives and  #MakeAmericaHealthyAgain.

I am honored to be selected as a member of the Republican Study Committee (RSC) Steering Committee. The policies and legislation we introduce and pass are more important than ever as we enter in to the 115th Congress. I look forward to working with the RSC, my fellow members of the Steering Committee and Chairman Mark Walker to develop and promote conservative and forward-thinking legislation that will help get our nation back on the right track.

Senator Jeff Sessions has demonstrated that a person of integrity and faith can serve in elected office in Washington and remain a person of integrity and faith. These are qualities of character, along with the unquestioned credentials, that Mr. Sessions possesses which will make him a great U.S. attorney general.  Read the column I wrote for Washington Times Opinion:

I have always believed that Senator Jeff Sessions would make an excellent United States Attorney General. Today Senator Sessions showed the American people his outstanding record and that he is a man of deep and unwavering integrity. I am confident the Senate Judiciary Committee will come together and favorably report Senator Sessions’ appointment to be the next Attorney General. Under Senator Sessions’ leadership, the Department of Justice will uphold and enforce the laws and the Constitution.

William Smith is a courageous, intelligent and honorable man. Today he testified in front of the Senate Judiciary Committee in support of a man he knows well, our next Attorney General, Senator Jeff Sessions.  William showed true bravery standing up and speaking from his heart while those who do not know William or Senator Sessions launched attacks on both of them.  I've said it many times before, but it truly cannot be said enough. I am honored to work with a man of such pure and godly integrity like William Smith.

Today I had the honor of presiding over the House floor during debate on the amendments to H.R. 78, SEC Regulatory Accountability Act. Watch the House in session here: www.c-span.org/video/?421742-101/us-house-legislative-business&live

Today the House took the first step toward dismantling Obamacare. Over the past 6 years, we have been forced to deal with this unaffordable mandate misnamed the Affordable Care Act. Too many people, including many of my constituents, lost insurance and doctors they liked. Healthcare premiums skyrocketed, deductibles soared, and healthcare options became limited. Now we have an opportunity to provide real healthcare solutions that put the people back in charge of their healthcare decisions.
Today we pause to the remember the life and legacy of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. #MLKDay

Every year I have the honor and privilege of nominating outstanding students from the Sixth District of Alabama for an appointment to our nation’s service academies. Service academy recruiters often compliment Alabama’s Sixth District for the level of preparedness and exceptional achievements of students from our area.   This year I am pleased to announce that 27 impressive students from the Sixth District have received nominations to attend U.S. Service Academies.  For the full list of nominations, click here: palmer.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/palmer-nominates-students-us-service-academies
Yesterday I joined WBRC FOX6 News' The Four. It was great talking with them about the inauguration and the incoming Trump Administration.

I really enjoyed spending time with this group of young professionals with the Birmingham Jewish Federation, and sharing thoughts on the United States’ relationship with Israel as well as what Congress has on the agenda for the next 100 days. Special thanks to Samantha Dubrinsky and Daniel Odrezin for coordinating this event.
Do you need help with a federal agency? A member of my staff will be in Goodwater next Wednesday from 10AM-12PM to assist you!

I offer my congratulations and prayers to our 45th President of the United States of America, Donald J. Trump, and Vice President, Mike Pence, as they serve the American people. This Administration has the opportunity to lead our country with dignity and to uphold the Constitution as our Founding Fathers intended almost 230 years ago. I look forward to working closely with President Trump and his Administration as we Make America Great Again.
I was so happy to have my amazing wife Ann by my side for the inaugural celebrations.
Tomorrow I'm hosting the first Pastries with Palmer of 2017! I hope to see you there.

I am honored to have the opportunity to serve the American people as the Chairman of the Subcommittee on Intergovernmental Affairs. Oversight of the relationship between the federal and state governments and international organizations is essential to America’s success. I look forward to continuing my work limiting government overreach and reining in burdensome regulations with this new subcommittee.

I am proud to say that today I voted in support of H.R.7, the No Taxpayer Funding for Abortion and Abortion Insurance Full Disclosure Act of 2017. This pro-life legislation permanently bans taxpayer funded abortions. This is an important step towards protecting the lives of babies in the womb.

President Trump gave a great speech today at the GOP retreat. His vision for what Congress and his Administration can do together to get our nation back on the right track was filled with great energy and optimism.

I wanted to share with y'all British Prime Minister Theresa May's speech from the GOP retreat. It struck me as Margaret Thatcheresque. It also should be noted that President Trump's first meeting with a head of state will be tomorrow with Prime Minister May. I look forward to seeing what comes from such a historic meeting.

Year after year the pro-life community has come to this city--our nation's capitol--to stand up for the right to life. I believe, and I pray, that very soon we will no longer need to gather here to mourn the anniversary of Roe v Wade. Instead we will gather here to celebrate the reversal of Roe and the restoration of the first right--the right to life.
Great news for small business owners! This new executive order reduces red tape by requiring the elimination of two regulations for every new regulation.
My January newsletter went out this afternoon. Make sure to read it if you haven't gotten the chance already.  Sign up to receive my newsletter here: palmer.house.gov/contact/newsletter

The nomination of Judge Neil Gorsuch to the Supreme Court is a great choice for our country. I believe he will uphold the Constitution and not legislate from the bench. I look forward to my colleagues in the Senate quickly confirming Judge Gorsuch.

I applaud the Senate Judiciary Committee for voting in favor of Senator Jeff Sessions’ appointment as the United States Attorney General. This was a much overdue vote and I look forward to the majority of the Senate voting in favor of Senator Sessions’ appointment. He will defend our nation and serve the American people with dignity and reverence for the Constitution.

Today in the House Oversight Committee hearing, we had the opportunity to talk with Inspectors General. One thing we learned is since the implementation of the Inspector General Empowerment Act of 2016, IGs have experienced easier access to required documents. Yet, IGs still lack proper access to former federal employees after they retire or resign. Having testimonial subpoena power would help to provide access to key people in an IG investigation.

For too long Congress has granted federal agencies the authority to collect fines, fees and other revenues outside of their appropriated funds with little to no Congressional oversight on how the monies are spent. Congress’ power of the purse is exclusive and absolute and we must begin reclaiming our Article I authority. I am proud to team up with my colleague Senator Mike Lee on this important piece of legislation in both the House and Senate.

I am pleased to introduce a new segment I'm starting called Truck Talks. It's another way for me to share my views with you and I look forward to hearing your thoughts on the different issues that affect all of us. Today's Truck Talk is on energy!

Tonight Alabama has much to be proud of and the United States of America has a new Attorney General whom the country will be proud of as well. Attorney General Jeff Sessions will be a great asset to our nation as he follows the Constitution faithfully and works to restore respect for the law and confidence in our justice system. I applaud my colleagues in the Senate for voting to confirm Attorney General Sessions.

Congratulations to Luther Strange on his appointment to the United States Senate. I look forward to working with Senator Strange as we continue to promote and advance conservative legislation and true Alabama values.

At least a dozen agencies did not report improper payments this past year.This greatly concerns me and we must take steps to prevent this from occurring.

The Sixth District town hall meeting scheduled to be held at Hoover Tactical on Saturday February 25 at 9 AM is being relocated to Hoover City Hall. And while the response for the location has been supported by a majority of constituents in the District, a few people have expressed reservations. A town hall should provide the opportunity for District citizens to appreciate the venue and express their concerns respectfully, without disruption. I hope all participants will conduct themselves in a civil manner and act respectfully towards all who attend. I look forward to the town hall meeting and answering your questions about how I’m representing you.
This is great news and a huge step towards ridding our country of harmful over-regulation.

The recent threats against the Levite Jewish Community Center are serious and of great concern. Considering the fact that both this threat and previous threats are national in scope and obviously coordinated, they should be investigated as potentially terroristic. I call on our law enforcement officials to thoroughly investigate these threats and bring those who are involved to justice. The Jewish Community Centers are a vital part of the Birmingham community and communities across the nation. The people who work at the centers and the people they serve are friends and neighbors and we should stand with them against those who launched these threats.

I would like to thank the Greater Shelby County, Homewood, Hoover, Montevallo, Mountain Brook, South Shelby and Vestavia Hills chambers of commerce for inviting me to speak at their "Eggs and Issues" breakfast this morning.  It was a great opportunity to speak with the great people of the Sixth District and answer their questions about various topics ranging from healthcare to regulations to school choice.

Former Congressman Spencer Bachus and I were honored to present several well deserved awards and medals to the family of Melvin Spruiell, in appreciation as a grateful nation for the sacrifices he made in defense of our country. In June, 1944, serving as a Forward Artillery Observer with the 377th Parachute Field Artillery Battalion, First Lt. Spruiell exposed himself to enemy fire to locate a working radio in order to call in artillery to suppress and dislodge the enemy from their defensive position. Then, separated from his battalion, he volunteered as an infantryman and led a charge across an open field to take out an enemy machine gun nest. During that action, First Lt. Spruiell was killed.  His actions are in keeping with the highest traditions of military service and reflect great credit upon himself, the 101st Airborne Division, and the Army of the United States. We were truly privileged to have the honor of presenting First Lt. Spruiell's family with the following medals: the American Campaign Medal; the European-African-Middle Eastern Campaign Medal with Arrowhead Device; one Bronze Service Star, the World War II Victory Medal; the Purple Heart, and the Distinguished Service Cross. Men like First Lt. Spruiell are the reason America remains the home of the free and the land of the brave.
It was great getting to visit the Chilton County YMCA this morning. They are doing tremendous things for their community.

Yesterday, I toured the Boise Cascade Engineered Wood Products Plant in Thorsby. The plant produces laminated veneer lumber and employs over 240 people. Special thanks to Plant Manager Harry Marintsch.

Great to tour the YMCA of Chilton County in Clanton. The center offers afterschool programs to children in addition to healthy living programs for residents. Special thanks to Executive Director Lori Patterson, Clanton Mayor Billy Joe Driver, and the Chilton County Chamber of Commerce.
I look forward to seeing you bright and early in the morning at my Town Hall in Hoover!
Hoover Town Hall

It was an honor to take part in awarding Grayson Phillips of Gardendale with the rank of Eagle Scout.  According to the Boy Scouts of America, fewer than four percent of all Scouts earn Eagle Scout recognition, and 17-year-old Grayson, who was born with spina bifada, has been an example of determination and courage in achieving this goal. He has been and continues to be an inspiration to many, as evidenced by the attendance of so many of his family, friends, and neighbors who turned out at the Gardendale Civic Center  on Sunday.

I applaud President Trump for directing the Environmental Protection Agency and the Army Corps of Engineers to formally reconsider the Waters of the United States rule, also known as the Clean Water Rule. This rule, finalized under President Obama, represents a massive expansion of federal jurisdiction over bodies of water that rightfully belongs to states and localities. Everyone is for clean air and water. However, we must ensure that policies designed to achieve those goals respect the boundaries enshrined in our Constitution and do not create unnecessary barriers to economic growth nor do they compromise private property rights.

President Trump’s Joint Address to Congress measured up to the moment. He was presidential, presented a forward-thinking agenda and checked off every box for a  great speech. I look forward to working with the Trump Administration and Congress to translate the President’s message of optimism into sound policies that are beneficial to all Americans.
I was honored to meet President Trump at the Joint Address on Tuesday! Did you know that this was my first time meeting him? Thanks to John Lyda for the great photo. #tbt

Interior, Energy & Environment Subcommittee Chairman Congressman Blake Farenthold and I held a joint subcommittee hearing for his subcommittee and the Intergovernmental Affairs subcommittee, which I chair, today on environmental barriers to infrastructure development.  States and localities know the needs of their communities, we want to increase their ability to handle these projects. They should be trusted to use funds to fulfill those needs with the least federal government interference

I was honored to join my colleagues on the Faith and Politics Institute's 2017 Congressional Civil Rights Pilgrimage in Birmingham. We must never forget the past and must continue forging our path forward. Over the past few decades, Alabama has truly become a state of faith and forgiveness.

Today the White House reopened for public tours. A group of students from Briarwood Christian School were in for a special treat when President Donald J. Trump made a surprise appearance during their visit!  If you're interested in touring the White House, please visit my website to learn more:  palmer.house.gov/visiting-dc

I enjoyed touring the United Ability campus (formerly known as United Cerebral Palsy of Greater Birmingham). The organization does an outstanding job in caring for those with disabilities and helping to ensure that they have a brighter future. Special thanks to Dr. Gary Edwards and all of the UA staff.

Yesterday, I visited the Brookwood Baptist Medical Center Department of Anesthesia. I always appreciate seeing firsthand the amazing work performed by our medical professionals. Thanks to Dr. Abe Schuster, Dr. Matt Sherrer, Richard Carson, and Ross Mitchell.

I had the pleasure to speak at a program held by Samford University’s Department of Nutrition and Dietetics on Monday. The post-baccalaureate students there are preparing to become registered dietitian nutritionists. Special thanks to Samford President Dr. Andrew Westmoreland, Mim Gaines, and Susan Scott.

We held our first Sixth Congressional District Mayors Luncheon of 2017 at the Shelby-Hoover Campus of Jefferson State Community College on Monday. It’s always great to converse and share ideas from throughout the district. Special thanks to the students of the Culinary & Hospitality Institute.

Last night I attended a town hall at the Levite Jewish Community Center of Birmingham, along with representatives from the FBI, ATF, local law enforcement, Mayor Bell, and other elected officials, to express my continued concern and support in light of the recent and ongoing threats against this center. The people who work at the centers and the people they serve are friends and neighbors and we should stand with them against those who make these threats, not only in Birmingham but at similar community centers around the country. I urge everyone to be vigilant in reporting suspicious activity to their local law enforcement. My staff and I will continue to monitor the situation and engage with federal and local law enforcement agencies and officials, making sure they have the support of my office and of Congress.
It was an honor to participate in the Faith and Politics Institute's 2017 Congressional Civil Rights Pilgrimage with my colleagues last Friday.

Congratulations to Elizabeth Whidden for being named a School Nutrition Hero! Through her work as Hoover City School’s Child Nutrition Manager, Liz encourages the children to learn about food and nutrition empowering them through knowledge to make healthy lifestyle choices.

We have one opportunity to answer the healthcare crisis the American people are facing. In my opinion, the current bill does not answer this crisis. I voted against the American Health Care Act in the Budget Committee because the promises of changes in the future are insufficient. Now that the bill has been reported out of committee, I will continue to work for the changes that are necessary to ensure Medicaid is a viable and affordable program to provide healthcare to the people who need it most. In that regard, I believe block granting Medicaid to the states and requiring work for able-bodied working age adults are essential to achieving this objective. I look forward to working with my colleagues to make these and other improvements to this bill.
Tune in now to watch the Facebook live on my bill, the Agency Accountability Act.
Great meeting with the Canada-United States Inter-Parliamentary Group today.

I was excited to invite Pastor Scott Dawson to share his faith in Christ and the Gospel with my fellow members of Congress at the Jefferson Gathering. Having known Pastor Dawson for over 12 years, I thoroughly enjoyed his message of living a life of honor and integrity as we serve the American people.  In today’s modern and ever-changing world, it is more important than ever that we look towards our faith and God for guidance and hope.   The Jefferson Gathering is a nonpartisan opportunity open to all members of Congress and their staff that is held every week for spiritual inspiration and encouragement. The Jefferson Gathering worship services were started on July 30, 2014, after a 144-year absence. Beginning in 1800 under President Thomas Jefferson, Sunday Christian worship services were held in the Capitol until 1869. These services are so named in his honor.

I commend the FBI and Israeli police for their investigative work leading to the arrest of a suspect connected with a series of bomb threats to Jewish community centers across America and right here in Birmingham. Hopefully this arrest will bring peace of mind to our community and to the Levite Jewish Community Center. Individuals engaging in this type of conduct must be arrested and brought to justice and I highly commend our law enforcement and intelligence communities for their excellent work. No American should have to live in fear for themselves or their family because of their race or religion. Finally, I am very proud of how the greater Birmingham community came together to support and encourage the members of the Levite Jewish Community Center. It speaks volumes about our community.

My thoughts and prayers are with Bill Armistead and his family after the tragic accident that took the life of his wife, Emily. I have known Bill and Emily Armistead for over 25 years. Over the years, one of the things that stood out for me was how devoted Bill and Emily were to each other. My heart is absolutely broken. While there are no words that come close to being able to console Bill and his family, I am trusting that God will cover them in His loving embrace to give them consolation and reassurance of the hope they have in Jesus Christ. Bill and his family are in my prayers.

After hearing from me and many of my colleagues the Republican leadership decided not to hold the vote on the American Health Care Act. I believe pulling the bill from the House floor was the right call. The American people have suffered for the last 7 years under Obamacare, and I know we can provide them a better solution that will put healthcare decisions back in their hands, not in the hands of the Federal Government. I look forward to working with my colleagues in Congress and President Trump to do just that. Working together we can still pass a bill that allows Americans to access the doctors they want, decide the coverage they need, and lower their healthcare expenses.
It was great visiting with Darryl Colburn, the mayor of Hackleburg, last week. Did you know that I grew up in Hackleburg, Alabama?

As I sat in the House Oversight Committee hearing listening to the testimony, one word kept popping up in my mind. Incompetent.  It is unbelievable that we have state and local governments, including Alabama, looking for the manufactured housing units for disaster survivors, but can't get enough from FEMA. But then FEMA sells these units through GSA for $11,000, which are worth around $70,000, for a tremendous loss to the taxpayers. This makes them look like the gang that can't shoot straight. It is disturbing to me that a federal agency has failed in so many respects.

President Trump conducted a strategic and necessary strike to send a message that we will not tolerate chemical weapons being used against innocent women and children. I applaud President Trump and the United States Military for their quick and tactical action against the Assad regime. In carrying out this strike President Trump showed that he has a line, a short line, when it comes to rogue regimes use of weapons of mass destruction.

I am pleased the Senate has confirmed Neil Gorsuch as the newest United States Supreme Court Justice. Justice Gorsuch's record indicates he will firmly defend the Constitution and protect the rights the Founding Fathers envisioned for the American people.

I believe Robert Bentley resigning as Governor of Alabama was the appropriate decision. The people of Alabama deserve a leader who is above reproach and governs our great state without distractions. This action is the first step to allow the people of Alabama to finally move on from this situation.

On this day 6 years ago our state experienced a day of death and destruction of enormous scale losing 252 lives, with more than a 1,000 people injured as over 60 tornadoes ripped through Alabama. My own hometown of Hackleburg was hit by an EF-5 tornado. When I arrived to see the damage, my heart sank. My hometown was completely and utterly destroyed to the point where familiar places I had grown up seeing were now either gone or unrecognizable. But in Alabama, we don’t let things bring us down for long. Instead we come together and build ourselves and our neighbors back up. On that day and on those days following, the people of Alabama came together helping their loved ones, neighbors and even strangers recover and rebuild their lives. While we remember with great sadness those we lost on April 27th, 2011, we also remember with great pride how people from all over the state of Alabama came together to help each other recover and rebuild.
This weekend Hoover celebrates it's 50th anniversary! They're hosting a great day of family fun for everyone tomorrow.
Great seeing the Briarwood Fellows before they went on a tour of the Capitol!
Each year I enjoy seeing all of the talented student artists and their work at our Congressional Art Competition.

Today the House of Representatives took the first step toward repealing and replacing the misnamed Affordable Care Act and restoring access to affordable healthcare for all Americans. The amendment that I authored on invisible risk sharing will drive down the cost of health insurance premiums and helps ensure that those with preexisting conditions have affordable coverage. The option for states to choose to receive Medicaid funding as a per-capita cap or a block grant will provide states with more flexibility to meet the needs of their Medicaid eligible people and will reduce the waste of billions of Medicaid dollars to fraud, inefficiencies and mismanagement. The AHCA also gives states the option to establish work requirements for able-bodied adults without small children. Together, these additions to the AHCA are the most substantial entitlement reform in 50 years.  Although states, as they should be, are provided the option to seek waivers from certain federal mandates, states must certify that pursuing a waiver is for the purpose of expanding coverage or reducing the cost of healthcare.  There is no underlying intention to exclude people from coverage, including those who have been previously sick, and it is important to note that this bill will not exclude people from coverage. There is a little known provision in the bill which defunds Planned Parenthood for one year and will protect this lives of the unborn. This bill is not the end of our efforts to dismantle Obamacare and repair the damage done to our healthcare system. It is the first major step forward.

I was pleased to author an amendment to the AHCA with Congressman Schweikert modeled after reforms implemented in Maine that will significantly lower premiums for individuals purchasing coverage in the individual market.
A great read from the The Daily Signal: "The Agency Accountability Act would bring much-needed accountability to federal agencies and empower Congress to reclaim its rightful power of the purse."
